utterances: Well, on a bittersweet note, we have Life magazine, the publication that introduced us to the likes of photographer Gordon Parks.
And the magazine will print its final issue on April 20th.

Parent company Time Incorporated announced it's going to stop publishing the magazine that's been a weekly newspaper insert since 2004, and instead it's going to feature images from Life on the Internet.
You all - I grew up reading Life magazine.
How much of a loss is this?
Not a loss…
Not a loss.
I mean, I remember looking at Life magazine…
Not anymore.
…when I was young and you looked at those beautiful pictures…
Yeah.
…and it was a time when we didn't have any computers.
Now we open up our computers and we see the same beautiful pictures and it's no longer something that has to be put on a page anymore.
We get the same experience, and so naturally that physical object is no longer as important.
I'm having a very hard time getting used to the fact the printed page is less and less important in all areas of our lives because I like books, the page, I like smelling paper.
But it's a different era.
Technology has made a lot of it obsolete.
I'll make note of that.
I have credits that are available and ready to be transferred.
And, you know, I've not even felt the desire to read Life since it became an insert in Sunday newspapers.
It's just not that valuable a commodity anymore.
We do have that nostalgic feel for what it used to represent, but that's no longer the case.
And as John is saying, we can still find some of these images on the Internet.
We can still go to the library and look at all copies of Life and look and some other magazines.
But I think this is probably a wise business decision.
Well, this is the latest of several magazines that have ceased printing issues as people do go to the Internet.
So is this just typically a sign of the times or what do you make of this?
I think it's a sign of the times, definitely.
Publishing is a tough business.
I published a newspaper for 11 years, and when I had to make the decision to not do that anymore it really, really hurt.
You hate it because people lose jobs.
The population loses a voice in many ways.
We know that we're transferring now.
We're transitioning into an Internet-based society now, so we will miss some things in that transition.
And I too am very much a fan of the written word and the page itself.

But I'm also - in that - with that knowledge, I'm kind of excited that there will be a lot more online, especially access to photos and the work of Gordon Parks, another great photographer from Life, that we'll be able to now access on a whole new level.
So you take some and you lose some.
Yeah.
I was going to ask you that.
E.R., you talked about how you had kind of stopped reading it since it had become an insert; will you visit it while it's online?
Oh, I would love to see some of these images because we're told that most of them were never published.
So for someone who's interested not only in journalism but in history, I would love to be able to have access to some of these images and the stories behind them.
How lovely.
All right.
Well, thank you so much.
E.R.

Shipp is professor in journalism at Hofstra University School of Communication, John McWhorter is the Manhattan Institute senior fellow in public policy, and Jeff Obafemi Carr is host of the radio show ""Freestyle."" He was in Nashville, Tennessee, at Spotland Productions.
Thank you all so much.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
And as always, if you'd like to comment on any of the topics you've heard on our Roundtable, you can call us at 202-408-3330.
(Soundbite of music)
Next up on NEWS & NOTES, New Jersey legislation helped one lesbian couple take a big step in their relationship.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Cohen.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Coming up, we hear about Dennis Kucinich's first political campaign.
But first, General Motors workers are back on the job today after an early morning announcement of a tentative contract.
The United Auto Workers and GM reached the agreement after weeks of bargaining.
NPR's Celeste Headlee joins me now from Detroit.
Hi, Celeste.
Hi.
So both parties here issued statements to the media, but neither had much in the way of details.
Why no specifics?
Yeah.

They want to make sure that their members are getting the information and the details on the agreement from them directly rather than reading about it in the newspaper or hearing about it on the radio.
They want to make sure that they have informational meetings set up and they are able to explain the agreement before the ratification vote takes place.
And what will happen?
How will the union move towards ratification?
Well, they have a very specific process.

The first thing they have to do is fly many of their senior officers to different points of the country, carrying copies of the contract with them, and then they bring everyone together for informational meetings.

And once those informational meetings are over and done and everyone's had a chance to read it, then they probably will hold votes over the weekend, and members will be able to either place their ballots in the offices, in the plants, or go into their local office to vote.
This strike didn't last too long.
Do you think it made much of an impact on how the bargaining went?
That's pretty much the question of the hour, and there's no way to know.
I mean, because we don't have any details of the agreement, we're not really sure if the UAW got what they wanted.
Ron Gettelfinger has said - he is the president of the UAW, the National UAW, of course - and he said that he thinks the members and the retirees are going to be very happy.
But we don't know if that's true or not.
So until we're sure what the details are, until we know what GM promised in terms of job security, we're not sure what impact the strike had or didn't have.
So Celeste, more than 70,000 GM workers going back to work, how are they feeling about it?
I think they're pretty happy about it.
For one thing, it rained here in Detroit, so they're probably relieved they don't have to picket in the rain.
But you know, they were reluctant to go on strike as it was.
They didn't want to do anything that would hurt a company that was already in some kind of financial situation that was a little precarious.
And they certainly didn't want to hurt the union.
So nobody really wanted to go on strike.
They were disappointed to hear the news that they had to go on strike, and they're probably very, very happy to be back on the line.

I spoke with the president of chapter Local 22 that represents workers at the Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant, and he said the workers are anxious to get their hands on that agreement and take a vote this weekend.
NPR's Celeste Headlee in Detroit.
Thanks so much.
Thank you.

I'm Farai Chideya.

They're showing it off here.
Intel is putting a lot into this.
It is real.
